content:
• Thursday, February 18, 2016
  • IRT

    Independence REIT sells Atlanta apartments for $18M

    • Independence Realty Trust (IRT +4.6%) today sold a 222-unit apartment property for $18M.
    • The REIT will reap net cash of about $10M for selling the Atlanta property, after allowing for debt repayment and transaction costs.
    • It will recognize a gain of about $2.4M on the sale this quarter, and will apply the cash to its own debt.
    • At last report, it had a debt-to-equity ratio of 167, and debt-to-assets of just over 60.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:20 PM
  • OMEX

    Odyssey Marine Exploration sets 1-for-12 reverse split

    • Odyssey Marine Exploration (OMEX +9%), trading under $1/share since early 2015, is executing a reverse stock split.
    • A 1-for-12 reverse split will take effect after the close tomorrow, and stock will trade on a split-adjusted basis on Nasdaq on Monday.
    • The company's shareholders had authorized a 1-for-6 reverse split last June 9; the board then authorized an additional 1-for-2 reverse split to go along with it.
    • Each 12 shares of issued and outstanding common stock will become one share, and fractional shares will be rounded up. Authorized shares of common stock will be reduced to 75M from 150M shares, and immediately after the reverse split, Odyssey will have about 7.53M shares outstanding.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:57 PM | 23 Comments
  • FOX

    Deutsche Bank lowers targets, sees opportunity in media stocks

    • Battered media stocks came in for some (valuation-based) love from Deutsche Bank, which adjusted its price targets on a number of names today, with some of them at multi-year lows to create a "selective buying opportunity."
    • It saved its only price-target hike for one of its top picks, Time Warner (TWX -0.1%). Analyst Bryan Kraft raised his target on the stock to $93, from $88; that implies 44% upside from today's close of $64.62.
    • His other top picks in the sector include Twenty-First Century Fox (FOX -0.2%, FOXA -0.3%), Buy-rated but with a price target cut to $37 from $40 (implied 40% upside for FOXA); CBS (CBS -1.7%) and Starz (STRZA -3.1%).
    • Also coming in for target cuts also were Walt Disney (DIS -0.3%), lowered to $113 from $114, implying 18.7% upside, and Viacom (VIA -0.4%, VIAB -0.4%), cut to $38 from $56, implying 6% upside on B shares.
    • It's been a rough winter for most of the stocks. Returns over the past three months: TWX -10%, FOXA -12.9%, CBS -10.8%, STRZA -37.5%, DIS -19.4%, VIAB -32.8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:34 PM | 15 Comments
  • IRDM

    Iridium wins DOD order to modernize gateway

    • Iridium Communications (NASDAQ:IRDM) gained another 2.9% today, bringing it to an 11% five-day gain during a week of news where it started work on a next-generation satellite handset and signed up new partners for a push-to-talk platform.
    • Today, the company won an $8.57M task order from the Defense Information Systems Agency to modernize a dedicated Iridium gateway.
    • Aside from general improvements, the work will increase preparation for the Iridium NEXT configuration, its new-generation satellite constellation. That's scheduled to begin launches this year and finish up in late 2017.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:04 PM | 1 Comment
  • TI

    Regulator: Brazil should start fresh on telecom rules

    • Brazil should scrap its telecom regulations and start fresh, rather than focusing on some dated rules for required landline service, says an official with the country's regulatory agency Anatel.
    • That stance would line up with public comments from principals at Telecom Italia (TI +2.9%) and its TIM Participações unit (TSU +0.3%), as well as Oi (OIBR -9.4%) -- all of whom said that Brazil needs looser rules before some much-needed industry consolidation.
    • A number of players have tried to merge Oi with TIM for some time, though many have complained that Brazil's requirements for landline spending (dating to 1998) are getting in the way.
    • That framework is outdated because most Brazilians have phones and can choose from competition, says Anatel's Igor Vilas Boas de Freitas. He's calling for the agency to create an entirely new plan with 40 days, which would then go to the Communications Ministry and President Dilma Rousseff for approval.
    • The commissioners also postponed a vote on whether Oi could keep part of the $1.1B it owes in fines to use for service improvements.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:49 PM
  • ANET

    Arista up strongly after Q4 beat, solid Q1 guidance

    • Arista Networks (NYSE:ANET) is up 6% after hours to $61.65 after beating Q4 estimates (significantly on EPS) and guiding for Q1 revenue of $232M-$240M, favorable at the midpoint to a $233.6M consensus.
    • Slower spending growth boosted Q4 EPS: GAAP operating expenses rose 38% Y/Y to $106.8M (compares with 41.5% revenue growth), a marked slowdown from Q3's 65%. Non-GAAP gross margin was 64%, down 150 bps Q/Q and 340 bps Y/Y, but in-line with guidance of 62%-65%. Q1 GM guidance is also at 62%-65%.
    • Product revenue rose 38% Y/Y to $217.3M. Service revenue (boosted by software subscriptions) rose 72% to $28.1M. Arista ended 2015 with $687M in cash, no debt, and a $195M deferred revenue balance (up from $106M at the end of 2014).
    • The numbers come after major client Facebook forecast capex will rise to $4B-$4.5B in 2016 from 2015's $2.5B. Google has also forecast its capex will rise in 2016, after having surprisingly dropped in 2015.
    • Arista's Q4 results, earnings release
     
     
     
     
    | 6:32 PM
  • SXC

    SunCoke Energy confirms plan to suspend dividend

    • SunCoke Energy (NYSE:SXC) -7.1% AH after confirming its previously announced plan to suspend its common stock dividend.
    • SXC says the suspension is part of its revised capital allocation strategy to maintain a solid liquidity position against challenging market conditions.
    • SXC says it ended 2015 with more than $275M of total liquidity, including $123M in cash and $155M available in its revolver.
    • Earlier: SunCoke Energy, SunCoke Partners soar on EBITDA guidance (Dec. 17)
     
     
     
     
    | 6:32 PM | 9 Comments
  • SUNEQ

    SunEdison fails to get lift from materials restructuring; SEMI soars on buyout hopes

    • Beaten-down SunEdison (SUNE) fell another 9.6% today to $1.51. Shares touched their 52-week low of $1.37 (hit on Friday and Tuesday) before bouncing a little.
    • The decline followed news SunEdison is restructuring its solar materials ops to focus on "asset-light proprietary silicon production technologies via partnerships and joint ventures." The efforts include shuttering a Pasadena, TX polysilicon plant, selling a Kuching, Malaysia solar plant to China's LONGi Silicon Materials, and turning a Portland, OR facility into "a cost-effective R&D and technology demonstration center." $266M in non-cash impairment charges and $171M in other restructuring charges are expected.
    • Meanwhile, former chip wafer unit SunEdison Semiconductor (NASDAQ:SEMI) finished up 51.4% after announcing it will explore strategic alternatives "following receipt of unsolicited preliminary indications of interest in the company." Barclays has been hired to assist with the effort, which comes with SEMI trading at a fraction of its 52-week high of $27.93.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:53 PM | 64 Comments

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5.25 p.m.: SRT +17.4%. CNA +10.4%. AHS +7.8%. AMAT +7.2%. ANET +6.8%.
    • Top losers, as of 5.25p.m.: TRUE -16.5%. TRN -14.7%. AFOP -13.8%. AU -10.4%. JWN -8.1%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:44 PM | 2 Comments
  • TRN

    Trinity Industries -15% on weak 2016 outlook

    • Trinity Industries (NYSE:TRN) -14.8% AH, on top of a 4% drop in today's regular trade, after Q4 earnings beat estimates but amid guidance that falls well below Wall Street estimates.
    • TRN estimates FY 2016 EPS of $2.00-$2.40, vs. the $3.65 analyst consensus estimate, assuming that "the current weak market conditions will continue throughout the year."
    • TRN says it is now expecting fewer new orders for railcars and deteriorating demand in its barge business, and will focus on containing costs.
    • Greenbrier (NYSE:GBX) -8.2% AH following TRN's results.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:18 PM | 27 Comments
  • MCHX

    Marchex beats with revenue growth of 12%

    • Marchex (MCHX +3.4%) logged largely in-line results in a Q4 report where it grew GAAP revenues 12% and sold non-strategic assets to focus on mobile analytics.
    • Call-driven and related revenue of $34.3M (up 13%) was the bulk of the total. Call-drive adjusted EBITDA was $2.5M, down 26.5%.
    • Revenues at its non-core Archeo unit were $0.6M, down from the prior year's $0.9M; Marchex logged a Q4 gain on the sale of Archeo assets of $1.5M. Last April, it had sold the bulk of Archeo's domain portfolio for $28.1M in cash along with some earn-outs based on sales targets.
    • It's guiding to call-driven revenue (including YP) of $35M or more for Q1, and adjusted EBITDA ranging from -$1.5M to $0.5M.
    • Shares are flat in after-hours trading so far.
    • Conference call link
     
     
     
     
    | 5:10 PM
  • YUME

    YuMe beats on top, bottom lines; sets first buyback

    • YuMe (YUME -3.4%) posted net income that dropped slightly but beat consensus expectations, and revenues beat soundly and the company authorized its first buyback.
    • EBITDA was $5.6M, which beat an expected $3.5M. EBITDA margin rose to 10.4% from a previous 8.1%.
    • The company logged 601 advertising customers for Q4 (up 12% Y/Y), and 1,001 ad customers for the full year (up 14%).
    • YuMe set a $10M share repurchase program (its first), and based on recent trades it represents about 9% of outstanding shares.
    • It's guiding to Q1 revenues of $35.5M-$37M (above consensus for $35.3M), and adjusted EBITDA of -$2.5M to -$1.5M (vs. expectations for -$1.9M).
    • Conference call to come at 5 p.m. ET
     
     
     
     
    | 5:00 PM | 3 Comments
  • TRUE

    TrueCar tumbles after Q4 miss, weak Q1/2016 guidance

    • In addition to missing Q4 estimates, TrueCar (NASDAQ:TRUE) is guiding for Q1 revenue of $60M-$62M and 2016 revenue of $270M-$275M, below consensus estimates of $69.2M and $309.8M. Adjusted EBITDA is expected to be "breakeven" in both Q1 and 2016 after totaling $7.6M in 2015.
    • New CEO Chip Perry, who has promised to improve TrueCar's occasionally frosty relationships with dealers, says the company is "embracing a new philosophical rudder and a new set of core business principles." Those principles include striving to be "a specialized two-sided digital marketplace" that aims to lower transaction friction while also providing dealers and automakers with a strong marketing ROI. and to explain TrueCar's value proposition to consumers "in a way that does not reflect negatively on car dealers."
    • Q4 metrics: Average monthly unique visitors rose 34% Y/Y to 5.9M. However, units rose just 12% to 183,157, a slowdown from Q3's 21% growth. Monetization (average transaction revenue) was flat Q/Q and up $10 Y/Y to $324. Franchise dealer count rose by 392 Q/Q to 9,094.
    • Financials: GAAP costs/expenses rose 39% Y/Y to $90.8M, easily outpacing revenue growth of 15% - $34.9M was spent on sales/marketing, $29.9M on G&A, and $14.9M on R&D. TrueCar ended 2015 with $112.4M in cash and no debt.
    • TRUE -12.3% after hours to $5.06.
    • TrueCar's Q4 results, earnings release
     
     
     
     
    | 4:53 PM | 2 Comments
  • AMBC

    Ambac Financial EPS of $10.64

    • Ambac Financial (NASDAQ:AMBC): Q4 EPS of $10.64 may not be comparable to consensus of $1.15.
    • Revenue of $170.73M (+94.7% Q/Q) beats by $46.93M.
    • Shares +1.9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:35 PM
  • VEON

    VimpelCom announces settlements with U.S., Netherlands; paying $795M

    • Confirming earlier reports, VimpelCom (VIP -1.6%) says it's reached approved settlments with the SEC, the Justice Dept. and the Dutch Public Prosecution Service related to probes of its business dealings in Uzbekistan and with Takilant Ltd.
    • VimpelCom will pay $795M in aggregate as part of the settlements, and its Uzbekistan subsidiary Unitel has entered a guilty plea with the Justice Dept. It had made a set-aside of about $900M to cover anticipated payments.
    • The carrier has agreed to oversight from an independent monitor who'll watch for compliance enhancements at the company.
    • Shares had gained 12.5% yesterday on word that settlements were coming; they're down 0.4% after hours today.
    • Previously: Telenor taking VimpelCom news 'very seriously'; VIP +12.5% (Feb. 17 2016)
    • Previously: VimpelCom up 6.2% on word it's settling Uzbek probes (Feb. 17 2016)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:33 PM
  • ATW

    Atwood Oceanics cancels quarterly dividend

    • Atwood Oceanics (NYSE:ATW) -2.9% AH after eliminating its quarterly dividend, a move it says will provide "greater flexibility to weather the current downturn."
    • ATW paid a dividend of $0.075/share in the previous quarter, which was cut from a prior $0.25/share payout.
    • ATW says the elimination will save the company nearly $5M/quarter.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:30 PM | 7 Comments
  • AFOP

    Alliance Fiber slides following Q4 miss, soft Q1 guidance

    • Alliance Fiber (NASDAQ:AFOP) is down 5.7% after hours to $13.50 after missing Q4 estimates and guiding for Q1 revenue of $17M-$19M, below a 3-analyst $19.7M consensus. EPS is expected to "improve" from Q4's $0.05, which was hurt by a foreign subsidiary annual tax adjustment; the Q1 EPS consensus is at $0.25.
    • No explanation is given in the earnings release for the results/guidance. In November, AFOP blamed its Q3 miss on "the effect of inventory control by our largest Web 2.0 customer," while insisting the inventory correction is temporary. Optical component peers Oclaro and Fabrinet provided strong results/guidance earlier this month.
    • Financials: In spite of the Q4 miss, gross margin rose to 41.2% from 40.1% in Q3 and 40.3% a year ago. GAAP operating expenses fell by $33K Y/Y to $3.35M - $2.3M was spent on SG&A, and $1.1M on R&D. 2.5M shares were repurchased over the whole of 2015. AFOP ended the year with $24M in cash, $10.8M in long-term investments, and no debt.
    • Alliance Fiber's Q4 results, earnings release
     
     
     
     
    | 4:26 PM
  • JWN

    Promotions and mix wreck margins at Nordstrom

    • Nordstrom (NYSE:JWN) tilts lower in AH trading after coming up short with Q4 results.
    • The company's gross profit rate fell 180 bps to 34.9% of sales, due chiefly to a higher level of promotions.
    • Comparable-store sales were up 0.2% for full-line stores. The off-price comp was +3.6%.
    • Sales off of Nordstrom.com improved 11% Y/Y.
    • Nordstrom sees sales increasing in a range of 3.5% to 5.5% this year. The outlook for full-year EPS is $3.10 to $3.35 vs. $3.53 consensus. A higher mix of online and Rack sales may be a factor.
    • Previously: Nordstrom misses by $0.05, misses on revenue (Feb. 18)
    • JWN -6.3% AH to $49.40.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:25 PM
  • AMN

    AMN Healthcare Services beats by $0.06, beats on revenue

    • AMN Healthcare Services (AHS): Q4 EPS of $0.47 beats by $0.06.
    • Revenue of $402.55M (+43.9% Y/Y) beats by $14.94M.
    • Shares +5.23%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:23 PM | 3 Comments
  • EQIX

    Equinix -2.2% as swing to profit comes in under expectations

    • Equinix (NASDAQ:EQIX) is off 2.2% in late trading after it swung to a net gain in income in Q4, but EPS of $0.18 fell well below expectations for $1.17, and funds from operations that declined 8% Y/Y were light as well.
    • Revenues were $730.5M in Q4 (up 14% Y/Y and up 6% sequentially), including $21.6M from its acquisition of Bit-isle. Recurring revenues were up 13% to $686.1M, also up 6% sequentially.
    • Monthly recurring revenue churn was 2.3%, up slightly from the previous quarter's 2%.
    • Including forecasts from acquisitions of Telecity (from Jan. 15, 2016) and Bit-isle (for the full year), Equinix is guiding to Q1 revenues of $838M-$842M (above consensus of $756.8M), including $117M in revenues from the acquisitions. Q1 adjusted EBITDA is expected between $368M-$372M (above expectations for $362.4M).
    • For the full year, it's expected revenues of more than $3.55B (vs. expected $3.26B) and EBITDA of more than $1.62B (vs. expected $1.55B).
    • Conference call to come at 5:30 p.m. ET.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:22 PM
  • BJRI

    Extra stores help leverage costs for BJ's Restaurants

    • Comparable-restaurant sales were up 0.7% for BJ's Restaurants (NASDAQ:BJRI) in Q4.
    • Total revenue was up 9% to $233M with 15 restaurants added since the year-ago period,
    • Restaurant-level cash flow rate +150 bps to 19.9% as sales leverage played in.
    • Expenses as a percentage of sales: Cost of sales -90 bps to 24.7%, Labor and benefits -50 bps to 34.2%, Occupancy flat at 21.2%.
    • BJRI +1.13% AH to $44.03.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:14 PM
  • ANET

    Arista beats by $0.19, beats on revenue

    • Arista (NYSE:ANET): Q4 EPS of $0.80 beats by $0.19.
    • Revenue of $245.44M (+41.5% Y/Y) beats by $4.34M.
    • Shares +3%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:13 PM | 1 Comment
  • CENX

    Century Aluminum beats by $0.08, beats on revenue

    • Century Aluminum (NASDAQ:CENX): Q4 EPS of -$0.53 beats by $0.08.
    • Revenue of $383.9M (-30.4% Y/Y) beats by $15.74M.
    • Shares +3.5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:13 PM
  • AMAT

    Applied Materials beats estimates, issues strong guidance; shares jump

    • Applied Materials (NASDAQ:AMAT): FQ1 EPS of $0.26 beats by $0.01.
    • Revenue of $2.26B (-4.2% Y/Y) beats by $20M.
    • Orders totaled $2.28B, down 6% Q/Q and flat Y/Y.
    • Expects FQ2 sales to be up 5%-10% Q/Q. Implies revenue of $2.37B-$2.49B, above a $2.28B consensus.
    • Expects FQ2 EPS of $0.30-$0.34, above a $0.26 consensus.
    • Shares +6.9% after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:07 PM | 4 Comments
  • ITRI

    Itron surges to new 52-week highs after Q4 beat, mixed 2016 guidance

    • Itron (ITRI +8.5%) has joined the very limited ranks of tech companies to have made new 52-week highs in February after beating Q4 estimates and reporting bookings of $822M (good for a 1.7x book-to-bill ratio).
    • The smart grid hardware/software provider is guiding for 2016 revenue of $1.85B-$1.95B and EPS of $1.95-$2.25 - the former is below a $1.99B consensus, but the latter is in-line with a $2.13 consensus.
    • Strong water segment sales (+13% Y/Y exc. forex) fueled the Q4 beat. Bookings growth led total backlog to rise 4% Y/Y to $1.55B, and 12-month backlog to rise 11.5% to $833M. Lifting EPS: Gross margin rose 140 bps Y/Y to 31.7%, and sales/marketing, R&D, and G&A spend each fell over 10% Y/Y with the help of job cuts.
    • Itron's Q4 results, earnings release
     
     
     
     
    | 4:00 PM
  • IQNT

    Inteliquent off 2.7% on Q4 earnings miss

    • Inteliquent (NASDAQ:IQNT) is down 2.7% after its Q4 earnings missed on the top and bottom line, though revenues gained nearly 32% Y/Y.
    • EBITDA of $18.4M missed an expected $19.1M. Minutes of use increased 31.5% in Q4, to 46.3B minutes, while average rate per minute increased 5.7% to $0.00166.
    • Network and facilities expense rose 93% due to increased traffic; the company hit traffic growth from an agreement with T-Mobile of 15%.
    • Free cash flow was $12.9M, down from the prior year's $16.3M.
    • The company's guiding to full-year revenues of $370M-$390M (above consensus for $338.2M) and EBITDA of $82M-$92M (light of expectations for $96.3M). It also sees $25M-$28M in capital expenditures.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:46 PM
  • UPL

    Ultra Petroleum flirts with bankruptcy after $3.2B Q4 loss

    • Ultra Petroleum (UPL -37.1%) is trying to avoid filing for bankruptcy after reporting a $3.2B Q4 net loss and $3.39B in debt.
    • President/CEO Mike Watford says he is trying to restructure UPL’s debt - “so far unsuccessfully" - in order to avoid filing in bankruptcy court, but admits the company needs external assistance.
    • UPL says it is reducing its capital spending for 2016 by nearly 50% to $260M from $500M, as the CEO says the hope is to survive current low natural gas prices and start profiting again next winter.
    • This year’s relatively warm winter likely was the “last nail in the coffin" for UPL with reduced natural gas demand, says Stifel analyst Michael Scialla.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:23 PM | 6 Comments
  • TRN

    Trinity slapped with Sell rating at Axiom, which sees reduced earnings ahead

    • Trinity Industries (TRN -3.4%) is initiated with a Sell rating and $10 price target at Axiom Capital, which believes reduced demand for railcars and an increased railcar backlog indicate reduced earnings for the company.
    • Axiom's Gordon Johnson thinks TRN’s fundamentals are on the “precipice of a severe correction lower," and expects the deterioration in the company’s earnings to outpace other rail leasing companies since the pressure on the average selling price on cars sold is immediately reflected in TRN’s rail group results.
    • Among the major risks Johnson sees facing TRN: the largest upcycle in railcar backlog due to the abrupt ending of the China commodity and U.S. energy booms and deteriorating rail demand, significant capacity additions by TRN to meet the demand for tank cars resulting in increased manufacturing expenses, and the new regulations allowing railcars to stay in service until 2020.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:12 PM | 12 Comments
  • STNG

    Scorpio Tankers upgraded to Buy at Deutsche Bank

    • Scorpio Tankers (STNG +4.6%) is upgraded to Buy from Hold with a $9 price target at Deutsche Bank, which it says reflects compelling valuation following the recent selloff and its confidence in management's willingness to be opportunistic in capturing dislocations for the benefit of shareholders.
    • The firm says it expects valuation levels to compel management to be more aggressive on share repurchases and even lead to asset sales, which would be immediately accretive to equity value given discount to NAV.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:59 PM | 7 Comments
  • UDF

    UDF down 50% as FBI raids office

    • The subject of Ponzi scheme allegations by Kyle Bass, the United Development Funding (UDF -54.6%) office in Grapevine was raided today by the FBI.
    • Agents were seen carrying boxes from the office into large trucks, according to the local NBC affiliate.
    • Previously: Kyle Bass discloses short in United Development Funding IV (Feb. 5)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:54 PM | 47 Comments
  • MEP

    Midcoast Energy Partners downgraded at Credit Suisse

    • Midcoast Energy Partners is downgraded (MEP -10.3%) to Underperform from Outperform with a $5 price target, slashed from $16, at Credit Suisse, which says that although the company made progress in 2015, it was inadequate in the face of its rapidly deteriorating fundamentals.
    • In its Q4 earnings report, MEP's Q4 adjusted EBITDA of $27M came in better than expected, but distributable cash flow of $16 million fell short of estimates due to high maintenance capex and interest expenses, and the company’s guidance for 2016 came in 39% below the consensus, prompting a 21% plunge in the unit price yesterday.
    • MEP needs $40M in support from Enbridge Energy Partners (EEP +5.2%) to pay 2016 dividends, Credit Suisse says.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:49 PM | 9 Comments
  • LOPE

    Grand Canyon Education shoots higher after earnings and DB upgrade

    • Grand Canyon Education (LOPE +12.8%) rallies after reporting above-consensus results and receiving a shot in the arm from Deutsche Bank.
    • The investment firm backed its Buy rating and $45 price target on the education stock in a fresh note to clients.
    • Shares of Grand Canyon touched $40 earlier today for the first time since the beginning of the year.
    • Previously: Grand Canyon Education beats by $0.02, beats on revenue (Feb. 17)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:38 PM | 2 Comments
  • SRE

    California gas leak permanently sealed, state officials say

    • The gas leak that raged for nearly four months and drove thousands of Los Angeles-area families from their homes has been permanently sealed, state officials say.
    • The announcement certifying that the ruptured well that spewed massive amounts of methane had been plugged with cement brought a point of closure in the drama that has disrupted life in the Porter Ranch community and drawn attention to the underground storage facility owned by Sempra Energy (SRE +1.6%) subsidiary SoCalGas.
    • Families staying in hotels or with friends and relatives will have eight days to return before the gas company stops reimbursements.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:38 PM
  • LSCC

    Lattice Semi surges after Q4 miss, soft Q1 guidance, in-line 2016 view

    • Lattice Semi (LSCC +13%) missed Q4 estimates and is guiding for Q1 revenue of $95M-$101M, below a $111.7M consensus. However, 2016 revenue guidance of $460M-$470M is in-line with $464.1M consensus.
    • A "payment delay" for an IP contract had a $7M impact on Q4 revenue. Lattice plans to recognize the contract's revenue once payment is received.
    • CEO Darin Billerbeck notes other issues are also weighing. "[W]e had expected our revenue to be substantially higher at our largest OEMs. Clearly, macro-economic challenges, including softness in multiple segments of the consumer market, impacted both our Imaging and FPGA businesses more severely than anticipated."
    • He adds the Silicon Image acquisition reduces Lattice's dependence on major OEMs, while adding imaging and millimeter-wave ICs to its product line. Lattice has "identified and actioned" $49M worth of cost synergies related to the Silicon Image deal, and thinks it can reach a 20% op. margin by the end of 2016.
    • Lattice's Q4 results, earnings release
     
     
     
     
    | 2:34 PM
  • IDCC

    InterDigital up strongly after Q4 beat; per-unit royalties drive growth

    • InterDigital's (IDCC +6.1%) per-unit royalty revenue rose 21% Y/Y in Q4 to $59.6M. That helped offset a 5% drop in fixed-fee amortized royalty revenue to $31.7M.
    • Total revenue growth of 30% benefited from the inclusion of $19.5M in revenue related to past royalties and tech solutions work. Meanwhile, EPS benefited from a $2M Y/Y drop in operating expenses to $58.8M, the result of a 65% drop in IP enforcement and non-patent litigation spending to $5.1M. "Development" and SG&A spend rose moderately.
    • Officially, Q1 sales guidance of $99M-$102M (solely recurring revenue) is below a 3-analyst $105M consensus. However, as is its custom, InterDigital's initial guidance doesn't account for "any new patent license, technology solutions or patent sale agreements that may be signed, or any arbitration or dispute resolutions that may occur" during the rest of the quarter."
    • InterDigital's Q4 results, earnings release
     
     
     
     
    | 2:01 PM | 1 Comment
  • MX

    MagnaChip soars after Q4 beat, light Q1 guidance

    • MagnaChip (MX +13.4%) is up strongly after soundly beating Q4 EPS estimates. Though officially beating the revenue consensus by $2.4M, Q4 revenue of $152.4M was just slightly above the guidance ($152M) given in MagnaChip's Jan. 19 pre-announcement.
    • Q1 guidance is for revenue of $141M-$144M, below a 2-analyst $152M consensus. However, MagnaChip notes it's due to lose more than $10M in revenue from its 6" wafer fab, which is due to close at the end of February.
    • Q4 gross margin was 19.6% - down from 22.5% at the end of Q3 and 20.6% a year earlier, but above revised guidance of 19% and initial guidance of 14%-16%. GM is expected to rise to 21%-24% in Q1.
    • Also boosting EPS: GAAP SG&A spend fell by $3.4M Y/Y to $18.7M, and R&D spend by $1.6M to $18.9M. MagnaChip ended 2015 with $90.9M in cash and $224.2M in long-term borrowings.
    • CEO YJ Kim: "Revenue in the fourth quarter was at the high end of our guidance range and gross margin was better than expected, driven primarily by an increase in demand for AMOLED display drivers consumed by smartphone makers in China. Despite a weak macro environment, our foundry pipeline is filling, AMOLED demand is improving and our business is showing early signs of stabilizing."
    • MagnaChip's Q4 results, earnings release

    SunPower slumps after issuing soft Q1/2016 guidance; analysts defend

    • Though SunPower (SPWR -3.5%) beat Q4 estimates, the company is guiding for 2016 revenue of $3.2B-$3.4B, below a $3.42B consensus. GAAP net income guidance is at $0-$50M, and non-GAAP gross margin is expected to drop to 14%-16% from 2015's 23.9%. Deployments are expected to rise to 1.7GW-2GW from 2015's 1.15GW.
    • Q1 guidance is for revenue of $290M-$340M (below a $675.7M consensus), a GAAP net loss of $90M-$115M, and a non-GAAP gross margin of 12%-13%. The timing of revenue recognition for solar project sales can lead to big quarterly and annual sales fluctuations.
    • CEO Tom Werner was upbeat in his PR quotes: "In the power plant segment for the fourth quarter, we successfully met our project commitments, added to our pipeline and further built out our U.S. HoldCo asset base ... In North America, our [residential] performance was solid as our fourth quarter results exceeded plan, we gained market share and broadened our leasing footprint as megawatt installed growth exceeded 45 percent year over year ... In our commercial segment, we are well positioned for 2016, having added projects to our backlog and building our pipeline to over $1 billion."
    • Q4 details: Power plant revenue rose over 3x Y/Y to $1.05B (project timings). Commercial revenue rose 28% to $134.9M. Residential revenue fell 2% to $177.4M. 356MW of solar cells were produced vs. 361MW in Q3 and 313MW a year ago. MW recognized rose to 348MW from 208MW in Q3 and 294MW a year ago.

      Lifting EPS: Non-GAAP gross margin rose to 28.8% from 17.7% in Q3 and 8.3% a year ago. GAAP operating expenses rose 25% Y/Y to $138.3M. SunPower ended Q4 with $954M in cash, $500M in debt, and $1.11B in convertible debt. The company's project pipeline is now above 14GW.
    • Baird's Ben Kallo (Outperform rating, $44 target): "SPWR had strong Q4 results which exceeded estimates, partially due to the recognition of [the 50MW Hooper project] in Q4:15 instead of Q1:16, which caused SPWR to adjust 2016 guidance. Importantly, SPWR continues to see growing demand across all customer classes, and is confident in its ability to capture market share through capacity expansions and cost reductions. SPWR remains our favorite solar pick given its pipeline, technology, and balance sheet, and we would be buyers at current levels."
    • Deutsche's Vishal Shah (Buy rating, $37 target) notes management talked up the positive impact of the ITC extension on the earnings call, as well as the potential for module share gains as SunPower invests in its its P Series module line. SunPower plans to up its annual module production capacity to ~4GW over the next several years; 2016 capacity guidance is at 1.85GW.
    • SunPower's Q4 results, earnings release, slides (.pdf), datasheet (.pdf)

    • Wells Fargo cuts its rating on all upstream MLPs in its coverage to Underperform, the firm's equivalent to a Sell rating, and downgrades its sector rating to Underweight, citing the MLPs' high default risk and its belief that many "could have zero equity value" when their hedges expire over the next 1-2 years.

  • IBM

    More on IBM: Morgan Stanley upgrades, shares jump

    • Believing IBM's (IBM +5.7%) current valuation doesn't reflect the company's efforts to grow its cloud/analytics exposure, Morgan Stanley's Katy Huberty has upgraded to Overweight and set a $140 target.
    • Huberty: "IBM Strategic Imperatives - data, cloud, engagement - now make up 35% of revenue and grew 17% in 2015, or 26% at constant currency, reflecting a faster-than-expected transformation to higher growth / higher value solutions. For comparison, Microsoft Cloud (Azure + Office 365) accounted for 36% of revenue and grew 20% in 2015. Yet IBM's share price reflects a perpetual decline in residual income, and these higher growth categories are undervalued based on our sum-of-the-parts (SOTP) analysis."
    • Of note: While IBM's Strategic Imperatives revenue rose 17% in 2015, total revenue fell 9% (1% exc. forex) after adjusting for divestitures. Free cash flow rose by $700M Y/Y to $13.1B, but is forecast to drop to $11B-$12B in 2016.
    • Regardless, Huberty expects the perceived disconnect between IBM's growth efforts and valuation to correct itself with the help of disclosures at IBM's Feb. 25 analyst day, stabilizing revenue, and improving free cash flow. She goes as far as to argue IBM "warrants a premium over other hardware companies that haven't invested heavily to transform to new computing paradigms," and predicts the company will deliver 2% annual free cash flow growth over the next two years (better than a consensus of -5%).
    • Following Huberty's upgrade and news of the $2.6B Truven Health Analytics deal, IBM is a large-cap standout on a morning markets are nearly flat. Shares are now up 14% from last Thursday's 52-week low of $116.90. They trade for 9.4x a 2017 EPS consensus of $14.16.

  • AERI

    Aerie Pharma's Rhopressa shows no safety issues in late-stage study; NDA on tap for Q3; shares up 14% premarket

    • Thinly traded micro cap Aerie Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:AERI) is up 14% premarket on increased volume in response its announcement of positive one-year safety data on lead product candidate Rhopressa (netarsudil ophthalmic solution) 0.02%, a once-daily eye drop for lowering intraocular pressure (IOP), from a Phase 3 clinical trial called Rocket 2. The study has already demonstrated Rhopressa's non-inferiority (no worse than) to twice-daily timolol.
    • The first 118 patients treated with Rhopressa showed safety results consistent with the 90-day efficacy period, with no new adverse events and no drug-related serious adverse events. The most common adverse events was eye redness (conjunctival hyperemia), up 30% from baseline (76% of the events were considered mild), although 70% of those with prior eye redness had none at Month 12. Other adverse events included hemorrhages, corneal deposits and blurry vision, ranging in incidence from 5% to 23%.
    • Rhopressa demonstrated consistent lowering of IOP over the 12-month period.
    • The company expects to file its New Drug Application (NDA) with the FDA in Q3. The data supporting the application will come from Rocket 2 and Rocket 1.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:18 AM

  • DUK

    Duke Energy posts Q4 miss as warm winter hurts demand

    • Duke Energy (NYSE:DUK) -1.8% premarket after Q4 earnings fell short of expectations amid warmer weather in some of its markets.
    • DUK says Q4 earnings at its regulated utilities segment, its biggest, rose 9% Y/Y to $601M, helped by higher pricing and updated contracts with more favorable margins that countered the effect of record warm weather in the Carolinas and across the Midwest.
    • Q4 income in the international business fell 5.6% Y/Y to $68M, pressured by lower methanol prices, partially offset by an improvement in Brazilian operations; DUK has said it is looking to sell all or part of the international business.
    • DUK issues FY 2016 EPS guidance of $4.50-$4.70, in-line with analyst consensus.

  • VALE

    Vale iron ore production rises in Q4; full-year output hits record

    • Vale (NYSE:VALE) continued to ramp up iron ore production during Q4 even as prices fell in an oversupplied market, producing a record amount despite November's catastrophic dam break at its Samarco joint venture in Mariana, Brazil, that caused production there to fall 39% to 6.3M metric tons.
    • Vale says it produced 88.4M metric tons of iron ore during Q4, up 2.4% Y/Y, with total output for full-year 2015 of 345.9M metric tons, surpassing its target of 340M tons en route to a company record and a 4.3% rise from the previous year.
    • The world’s largest nickel producer as well as the world's top iron ore miner, Vale’s Q4 nickel output rose 12% Y/Y to 82.7K metric tons, while copper production rose 6.7% to 112.5K tons.
    • Vale -2.4% premarket.

  • ATHX

    Stroke patients treated with Athersys' cell therapy doing well one year after dosing; shares up 21% premarket

    • Micro cap Athersys (NASDAQ:ATHX) is poised to add to its 16% up move the past two days. Shares are up 21% premarket on increased volume stoked by the company's announcement of encouraging one-year follow-up data on ischemic stroke patients treated with its MultiStem cell therapy.
    • MultiStem-treated subjects not only continued to improve through the year, but demonstrated a significantly higher rate of "Excellent Outcome" assessment compared to placebo. The difference was most profound in those patients treated with MultiStem within 36 hours of the stroke.
    • At Day 365, 23.1% (n=15/65) of MultiStem-treated patients achieved Excellent Outcome status compared to 8.2% (n=5/61) for placebo (p=0.02). In stroke patients receiving MultiStem within 36 hours, 29.0% (n=9/31) achieved an Excellent Outcome (p<0.01).
    • Substantial improvements were also seen in the Barthel Index, a scale used to evaluate the ability of patients to live independently. 61.5% of MultiStem patients were rated excellent (score of at least 95) compared to 44.3% for placebo (p=0.05). The percentage increased to 67.7% for those who were treated within 36 hours (p=0.03).
    • All MultiStem patients experienced reductions in average initial hospitalization days, mortality, life-threatening events and infections.
    • Ischemic stroke is caused by the blockage of blood flow to the brain. MultiStem is an "off-the-shelf" regenerative medicine product that can be stored for years in frozen form. It promotes tissue repair and healing in a variety of ways, such as producing therapeutic factors in response to signals of inflammation and tissue damage.
